Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BCC: Developing a Research Community and Capacity for the Study of Cultural Heritage in Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cultural heritage represents the physical manifestation of the culture and history of a social group or region and forms a major component of a people's sense of identity. Intentional destruction of cultural heritage during intrastate and ethnonationalist conflict is a well-known but rarely studied phenomenon often designed to erase the presence and history of a rival social or ethnic group. Recent cases of such destruction include the 2001 demolition of the Bamiyan Buddhas in Afghanistan, the 2006 bombing of the al-Askari Mosque in Iraq, and the 2012 destruction of Sufi shrines in Timbuktu, Mali. Despite considerable scholarship about purposeful violations of civil and political rights during conflict, there is a general tendency to view damage to cultural heritage as an unfortunate collateral outcome, rather than as a deliberate tactic. Consequently, few studies have examined how damage to cultural heritage sites is linked to ethnic or sectarian violence. Understanding how heritage destruction is implicated in the trajectory of these conflicts will enable U.S. policymakers and other humanitarian agencies working in conflict zones to design more effective interventions.

This interdisciplinary project will convene a working group consisting of subject matter experts in archaeology, anthropology, and other allied fields; specialists in conflict studies from political science, geography, and sociology; and methodological experts from the data sciences. Over the course of a two-year period, this research community will develop common definitions and coding standards that will enable the future development of large-scale datasets documenting and quantifying the destruction of cultural heritage. In order to facilitate such a comparative study, there is a need to develop methods for integrating data about events, specific localities, historical trajectories, and social conditions that precipitate acute outbreaks of destructive violence, which includes damage to cultural heritage. The proposed coding standards will be evaluated with a proof-of-concept case study based upon the current conflict in Syria. The completion of this test dataset will establish best practices in coding cultural heritage destruction information as well as a case study on the relationship between sectarian violence and cultural heritage destruction. Findings of the study, as well as an assessment of the validity and reliability of the coding strategy will be made available through a web portal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The humanitarian and human rights communities are increasingly interested in the effects of conflict on cultural heritage. Though not as pressing a concern as the immediate provision of food, water, medicine, shelter, and other humanitarian necessities, the preservation and restoration of cultural heritage sites is a key component in the recovery of communities following traumatic events. The high profile targeting of cultural heritage sites by groups such as ISIS has demonstrated how targeting cultural heritage can play a major role in attacks on civilians and in ethnic cleansing. Furthermore, the widespread looting of cultural assets has provided a funding source for insurgents and terror groups.

The growing understanding of the importance of cultural heritage in conflict has given rise to questions about how and why sites are damaged. However, little quantitative research has been done on this subject. Acquiring real-time information about conflict areas is inherently difficult due to their inaccessibility, but satellite imagery analysis can provide valuable data regarding locations unreachable by on-the-ground investigators. To contribute to the understanding of cultural heritage in conflict, AAAS used this technology to systematically assess damage to a sample of 120 sites in Syria and determine risk factors for potential damage. 

The dataset of Syrian cultural heritage sites was created by combining an expert derived list of sites with data from the crowd sourced mapping platform, Open Street Maps. Sites were categorized as archeological sites, archives, cemeteries, cultural centers, historic structures, libraries, monuments, museums, religious sites, or other. The sample of 120 sites was selected through a stratified random sample based on those categories.  The sample was not spatially random, as cultural heritage sites are clustered near current and past population centers.

As no similar analysis had previously been performed, AAAS began the project with a review of existing literature on damage to cultural heritage and an assessment of Syrian UNESCO and Tentative UNESCO World Heritage sites to understand the types of damage that could be observed through satellite imagery.  Two reports were published, detailing the results of the satellite imagery assessments. Based on these exercises, it was determined that satellite imagery would be capable of identifying damage from economic and development activities, looting, military presence, neglect, and damage of unknown origins. A coding guide was developed detailing the types of observations to be recorded and a system was created for scoring damage to all types of cultural heritage sites on a 5-point scale.

 

Two images of each site were initially acquired for analysis. The first image, captured before the Syrian Civil War began, was used to determine the original status of each site. For the purpose of this analysis, May 2011 was used as the starting date of the civil war. With the conflict still ongoing, January 2015 was used as the cutoff date for analysis. Imagery from as close to these dates as possible was used for the initial analysis, though any image within six months was deemed acceptable. If initial analysis of the before and after images revealed damage to the site, additional intervening imagery was acquired to determine when the site was damaged and establish a timeline of events leading up to the damage.

In addition to assessing damage to each site, the area within a 2,500 meter buffer of each site was visually analyzed to assess factors that could indicate risk to the site. These primarily included signs of conflict, such as military vehicles, destroyed structures, and fortifications. All observations were recorded in a geodatabase, along with the dates the observations were present in the imagery, as well as other necessary attribute data to aid in contextualizing the analysis made by AAAS.

Of the 120 sites analyzed, a total of 22 were found to be damaged; 15 archeological sites and 7 religious sites. No damage to other categories of sites was observed, though the small sample size of the other categories limits the conclusions that can be drawn. Of the 15 damaged archeological sites, 9 were mildly damaged and 6 moderately damaged. Of the 7 religious sites, 2 were mildly damaged, 4 were moderately damaged, and 1 was destroyed. Signs of conflict were present within the buffer area of all 7 of the damaged religious sites and 13 out of 15 of the damaged archeological sites. In addition to the assessments of damage to cultural heritage sites, AAAS recorded the locations of thousands of incidents of conflict-related change as part of the risk analysis. In total, 6,820 km2 of 208 distinct images were analyzed and the locations and dates of appearance of 37,630 destroyed structures, 9,481 roadblocks, 869 craters, and 343 km of fortifications were recorded.
